skill.name: biopython
skill.description: Primary Python toolkit for molecular biology. Preferred for Python-based PubMed/NCBI queries (Bio.Entrez), sequence manipulation, file parsing (FASTA, GenBank, FASTQ, PDB), advanced BLAST workflows, structures, phylogenetics. For quick BLAST, use gget. For direct REST API, use pubmed-database.

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing reference materials for the Biopython library. No executable scripts, no network calls, no file system access beyond standard bioinformatics operations. All network operations documented are legitimate calls to official NCBI Entrez API endpoints.

content.value_statement: Working with DNA, protein, or RNA sequences requires specialized tools for format conversion, database access, and sequence analysis. Biopython provides a comprehensive Python toolkit for all computational molecular biology tasks.
actual_capabilities: Read and write sequence files in FASTA, GenBank, FASTQ, PDB formats
Access NCBI databases via Entrez API for PubMed, GenBank, and protein searches
Perform pairwise and multiple sequence alignments with substitution matrices
Run BLAST searches and parse XML results for sequence homology
Analyze protein 3D structures from PDB files with RMSD calculations
Build and manipulate phylogenetic trees from sequence alignments
limitations: Local BLAST requires BLAST+ command-line tools to be installed separately
Rate limits apply to NCBI Entrez API (3 requests per second without API key)
DSSP secondary structure analysis requires DSSP executable

use_cases.title: Download and analyze gene sequences
use_cases.description: Fetch gene sequences from GenBank, calculate GC content, and extract protein translations for comparative analysis.

use_cases.title: Build phylogenetic trees
use_cases.description: Align multiple protein sequences and construct phylogenetic trees with distance methods for evolutionary studies.

use_cases.title: Analyze protein structures
use_cases.description: Parse PDB files, calculate RMSD between structures, and identify binding site residues near ligands.

best_practices: Set Entrez.email before making NCBI API calls to comply with their usage policy
Use iterators for large sequence files to avoid loading everything into memory
Cache downloaded data locally rather than repeatedly fetching from NCBI
anti_patterns: Loading entire multi-gigabyte FASTQ files into memory at once
Making repeated API calls without rate limiting or caching
Running many small BLAST queries instead of batching or using local BLAST

faq.question: Which Python versions are supported?
faq.answer: Biopython requires Python 3.8 or later. NumPy is also required for most operations.

faq.question: What are the NCBI rate limits?
faq.answer: Without an API key, NCBI allows 3 requests per second. With an API key, this increases to 10 requests per second.

faq.question: Can I use Biopython with other AI tools?
faq.answer: Yes, Biopython works with any AI assistant that can write and run Python code, including Claude, Codex, and Claude Code.

faq.question: Is my data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: When using Bio.Entrez, your queries are sent to NCBI servers. No other data is transmitted. Set Entrez.email to identify yourself.

faq.question: Why is my BLAST search failing?
faq.answer: Common issues include invalid sequence format, network timeouts, or NCBI rate limiting. Check your sequence format and consider caching results.

faq.question: How does Biopython compare to other tools?
faq.answer: Biopython is the most comprehensive Python library for bioinformatics. For quick BLAST queries, consider gget. For direct REST API access, use pubmed-database.
